pageContext.description:
The sitter is shown as a half-length figure, facing right against a dark blue background. She is wearing a black dress with white sleeves. Numerous brocade bands are tied around the voluminous material to divide it into segments. She has two chokers, a chain and a large amulet with the linked letters MK around her neck. Her hair is covered with a gold and silver checked hairnet visible under the broad brimmed hat. It has a brocade patterning and small charms (an anchor, an hourglass, a mug, a ship, a book(?), a horn) dangle from its rim.
[Görres, cda 2016]

metadata.title: Katharina of Mecklenburg, Duchess of Saxony (1487-1561)

pageContext.provenance:
- Gotha, Art Cabinet, Friedenstein castle, Picture Gallery
- 1856 Ducal Art and Antiquities Collection, Coburg (Herzogliche Kunst- und Altertümersammlung der Veste Coburg (HKA))
- 1919 Kunstsammlungen der Veste Coburg (KVC) 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 136]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
Support:
- trimmed
- inactive woodworm damage with open channels, particularly along the edges 
- the horizontal join has been reinforced with four small balsa wood battens 
- the chamfer necessary to slot the panel into the present grooved frame was more recently increased in width to c. 4.5 cm. 
- the reverse has been stained a reddish-brown tone 
Paint layers:
- some craquelé and various small retouches, rough old fill at the top left, probably after paint loss 
Varnish:
- repeated application of a glossy varnish 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 136]

tests.text:
DESCRIPTION

Tools / Materials:
- dark, fluid medium and brush
 
Type/Ductus: 
- the underdrawing is barely visible; freehand 
- thin, long and unbroken lines where visible 
 
Function: 
- relatively binding for the final painted version; lines delineate contours; no representation of volume 
 
Deviations:
- minor alterations made during the painting process: sitter’s sleeve
 
INTERPRETATION

Attribution:
- not possible

[Smith, Sandner, Heydenreich, cda 2012]

Identification of wood species: beech wood

Dendrochronology: plank I 126 annual rings 1520 - 1395; plank II 178 annual rings 1521 - 1344

The youngest annual ring is from 1521.

[Klein report, 03.03.2016]

- beech wood
- two horizontally aligned planks. Plank I: 24 cm; plank II: 30 cm. 
- the panel was probably originally fitted in a grooved frame 
- the reverse of the panel exhibits toolmarks from a blockplane 
- the horizontal join is reinforced with glue soaked tow 
- Dendrochronology: the following annual rings were recorded and measured: plank I: 126 annual rings, 1520-1395; plank II: 178 annual rings, 1521-1344. Generally with beech wood the entire section was used and only the bark was removed, therefore a felling date of 1521 can be estimated. The wood was then seasoned for at least two years and could have been used from 1523 (Klein 2016).

- traces of gold along the edge of the panel suggest that the original frame was guilded with the painting fitted in it
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 136]
